text: I'm Jonah Freud.

I'm the owner 
of a cookbook shop in Amsterdam.
My shop already exists for 40 years.
I made a book last year for the Rijksmuseum, The Rijksmuseum Cookbook
And today i'm going to make you an apple pie, one of the recipes that's in the book.
We put some flour, of course, 300 grams.
We put a little bit of salt,
sugar,...
We cut the butter into pieces.
I use cold butter because we need a firm dough.
We put one egg in it
and two tablespoons of ice-cold water.
Mix the butter into the flour.
When the dough is really one smooth ball, we put it into a plastic film and leave it in the fridge for half an hour.
I'm going to start with the filling now.
We first soak the raisins in some hot water.
I had a mother - she died already years and years ago - who was really fond of cookbooks already.
In the Sixties of the last century - 1960/1970 - she already had many many cookbooks
from all over the world.
I think my passion starts there.
Years later, when I was 14 years old, a relative of the family started a bookshop
specialising in books on cookery and I asked her whether I could work for her for free.
I worked for a couple of years in her shop.

Then someone took over the shop 
and I didn't work there for five years.
Afterwards I heard that he wanted to sell the shop, and the moment I heard that I knew that was my thing.
So I took it over 28 years ago. At that moment my daughter was only three months old.
I got a son two years afterwards and they grew up in my shop.

They are also both totally 
fond of cookbooks and of cookery.

My love for cookbooks is even 
bigger than [that for cooking].

I read them like normal books, 
they are always beside my bed
and when I am going on a holiday I always bring some.
It's a disease, I always say.
But I never, never follow a recipe in a cookbook.
I like to read them, I like to read the different recipes, the different ways people make it...
but I always make my own.

Except, I must say, for baking, 
because you have to be very precise.
That's not my strongest point, I'm not very precise,
but when I bake I need to do it.
Our soaked raisins...
We put some sugar in the filling,
cinnamon, ...then we do a typical Dutch trick: that's putting some custard powder in it.
We're going to mix the filling...
Oh, I think it's time to roll out the dough, now.
It has been there at least half an hour.
We need a part for the top.

Breadcrumbs on the bottom, 
just to take all the moisture out of the filling
Put the filling into the dough.
You all see that I'm not the most structured baker.
But the taste is okay!
Into the oven, for an hour!

The nicest thing with apple pies 
is the smell in the house, of course.
A typical Dutch apple pie!
An "appeltaart", we say in Holland.
The nicest thing is to eat it warm, but you can also have it cold, it's also good.
I hope you enjoy it!
